metadata.chief_complaint: annual check, confidential time, positive depression screen, safety plan, therapy referral, consider SSRI

doctor.style: warm, unhurried, skilled at difficult conversations

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Hi Maya, hi Mrs. Torres. Here for the annual checkup?

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Yes. She hasn't been herself lately and I thought it was a good time to come in.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I'm fine, Mom.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Let's talk about how things are going. Maya, anything bothering you health-wise?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: No. I'm just tired.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: She's been sleeping all the time. And she quit the volleyball team, which she loved.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: That does sound like a change. Let me do your physical first, then we'll have some private time to talk. Standard for teens.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Blood pressure, heart rate, height, weight all look good. Let me listen to your heart and lungs.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Everything sounds normal. Mrs. Torres, I'm going to chat with Maya alone for a bit.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Of course. Maya, please be honest with the doctor.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Maya, this is a confidential conversation. What you tell me stays between us unless I'm worried about your safety or someone else's. Okay?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I want to ask you some questions. They might seem personal but I ask everyone your age. Any smoking, vaping, alcohol, drugs?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I drink sometimes at parties. Nothing else.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How often?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Like twice a month maybe.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How much when you do?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: A few drinks. I don't get wasted.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Okay. Are you dating anyone or sexually active?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: No.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Your mom mentioned you quit volleyball and you're tired a lot. What's going on?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I just don't care about anything anymore.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Tell me more about that.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Everything feels pointless. School, friends, sports. I used to love volleyball but I just... I couldn't make myself go.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: How long have you been feeling this way?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: A few months. Since like September.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm glad you're telling me this. I need to ask some harder questions, okay?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Have you ever thought about hurting yourself or not wanting to be alive?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Sometimes I think everyone would be better off without me.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Thank you for being honest. That took courage. Have you thought about how you would hurt yourself or made any plans?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: No. I wouldn't actually do anything. I just... the thoughts are there sometimes.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Have you ever tried to hurt yourself?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: No.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Do you have access to any medications, guns, or other things that could hurt you?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: There's like Tylenol in the cabinet. That's it. No guns.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Maya, what you're describing sounds like depression. It's a real illness, not a weakness. And it's very treatable.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I thought I was just lazy or whatever.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: You're not lazy. Your brain chemistry is off and it's making everything harder. We can help.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: How?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: There are two main treatments: therapy and medication. I think you'd benefit from both.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I don't want to take pills.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I hear you. Let's start with therapy and see how it goes. If that's not enough, we can talk about medication later. But I want you to know it's an option.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Okay. Therapy I can try.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to refer you to Dr. Lin, she's great with teens. Can you see her within the next week?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I think so.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Good. I also want you to come see me in two weeks so I can check on you. And I need you to promise me something.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: What?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: If those thoughts about people being better off without you get stronger, or if you ever think about actually hurting yourself, you'll tell someone. Me, your mom, a teacher, the crisis line. Can you do that?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Yeah. I promise.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: I'm going to give you the crisis line number too. It's there 24/7 if you need it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: We need to tell your mom about this. Not everything we discussed, but that you're struggling with depression and we have a plan.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: She's going to freak out.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: She's worried because she loves you. I'll help explain it to her. Ready?

script.speaker: teen
script.text: I guess.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: What's going on?

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Mrs. Torres, Maya has been struggling with depression for the past few months. She was brave enough to tell me about it, which is the first step to getting better.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Depression? Oh honey.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: She's safe right now. But she needs treatment. I'm referring her to a therapist, and I want to see her in two weeks. We may discuss medication at some point.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Whatever she needs. We'll do it.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Also, I'd recommend removing any medications from easy access at home. Lock them up or store them with a neighbor. Just as a precaution.

script.speaker: parent
script.text: Okay. I can do that today.

script.speaker: doctor
script.text: Maya, you're going to get through this. I'll see you in two weeks.

script.speaker: teen
script.text: Thanks.
